Setting up and funding your investment accounts

sections.title: Types of Investment Accounts
sections.content: The main types of investment accounts are brokerage accounts (for general investing), retirement accounts (401(k), IRA, Roth IRA), and education savings accounts (529 plans). Each serves different purposes and has different tax implications. Start with retirement accounts for their tax advantages.

points.title: Traditional Brokerage
points.description: Full control over investments, research tools, but requires more knowledge and time.

points.title: Robo-Advisor
points.description: Automated investing with low fees, good for beginners, limited customization.

points.title: Retirement Accounts
points.description: Tax-advantaged accounts like 401(k)s and IRAs with contribution limits and withdrawal rules.

sections.title: Start with Retirement Accounts
sections.content: If your employer offers a 401(k) with matching, contribute enough to get the full match before investing elsewhere. This is essentially free money.

sections.title: Evaluating Platforms
sections.content: Consider fees, minimum investment requirements, available investments, research tools, and customer service. For beginners, low-cost platforms with good educational resources are ideal. Compare expense ratios, trading fees, and account minimums before choosing.

sections.title: Choose Your Investment Platform
steps: Determine what type of account you need (brokerage vs. retirement)
Research 3-4 platforms and compare their fees and features
Open an account with your chosen platform
Fund the account and make your first investment

sections.title: Look Beyond the Marketing
sections.content: Many platforms offer sign-up bonuses or free trades initially. Focus on long-term costs, ease of use, and the quality of their investment options rather than short-term promotions.
